problem_text: Compare two data collection methods: self-reported journals vs. wearable trackers. Identify at least one bias in each.
solution_text: Journals may over- or underreport due to memory or social desirability bias. Trackers may glitch or miss context (e.g., walking with hands in pockets).

problem_text: In a study of 100 adults, walking more was associated with lower cholesterol. Can you conclude causation?
solution_text: Not necessarily — correlation doesn’t prove causation. Confounding variables (diet, stress, genetics) could explain the difference.

problem_text: Design a randomized experiment to test if walking causes lower cholesterol. Include control, treatment, and response variables.
solution_text: Randomly assign subjects to walk daily (treatment) or not (control). Measure cholesterol after 30 days. Control for age, diet, sleep, etc.

problem_text: Why might machine-generated data be trusted more than human-reported data? What are the risks of this assumption?
solution_text: Machines seem objective, but may miss cultural context, consent, or ethical nuance. Overtrust can lead to false confidence and harm.
